timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: It got moved to the wrong method I feel?
replies.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: @Arthur-Milchior - just confirming the follow-up comment was seen
replies.author: david-allison-1

timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: Yes. The current PR was based upon the last PR. I forgot to rebase onto master when the other PR was accepted, my bad
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

timeline.bodyText: Needs a better explanation that this clones into the provided object, and not the other way around. Maybe with the method name as well
timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText:
Done.
deepCloneInto  allows to do j.deepCloneInto(t) to state that j gets cloned into t.
Ideally, I would just want to pass a class T as parameter, and create a new T() inside deepClone but it seems to be impossible :(
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

replies.bodyText: It's such a shame that it's not possible - generic erasure strikes again. Could be done if you accept a Class<T>, but it doesn't seem worth it
replies.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: I don't know how to do it. But anyway, I believe that the most important part is having better typing across the code. This can always be improved later since this method is not used appart in the class inheriting directly from JSONObject
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

timeline.author: david-allison-1

timeline.bodyText: Not a change in this PR - but this line looks suspect (possibly an attempted fix for the corrupt dynamic decks)?
timeline.author: david-allison-1

timeline.bodyText: This looks good - flagging for second review that new JSONObject and new Model both perform a copy, and don't refer to the same object
timeline.author: david-allison-1

timeline.bodyText: This is actually different functionality - wrap vs deepClone. This looks OK, but flagging as you wrote the deepClone code
timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: Thanks for catching it, it would have been a mistake
